Title: The rise and tide of the minangkabau traditional trading in Kuala Lumpur: A preliminary research
Affiliations: Universitas Sumatera Utara, Malaysia; Universitas Kebangsaan Malaysia, Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Sismudjito, R.I., Universitas Sumatera Utara, Malaysia; Munaf, D.A.A., Universitas Kebangsaan Malaysia, Malaysia
Abstract: This article is discussing on how the rise and tide of Minangkabau traditional trading occur in Kuala Lumpur. The research focused on four areas in Kuala Lumpur, Chow Kit, Kampung Baru, Kampung Dato' Keramat and Mesjid India area, reveals that there are some small stalls of Minangkabau traditional trading are now owned by another Indonesian ethnicity such as Acehenese and Boyanese tribe. Meanwhile, some of the businesses are still possessed by Minangkabau tribe such as Nasi Padang and textile trading. The phenomenon is affected by the lack of business innovation, capital, local competitor and the fact that they are unable to follow the trend in business. Even though, there are some of well-developed traditional business run by Minangkabau people in Kuala Lumpur due to the existence of marketing creativity, innovative items, and the conducive partnership with another Minangkabau entrepreneurs in the textile merchant in form of kiosk or arcade in Mesjid India area that has connection with another counterpart of the nationwide including Sabah and Sarawak. © 2015 Faculty of Geography UGM and The Indonesian Geographers Association.

Title: Geospatial analysis of road traffic accidents, injuries and deaths in Nigeria
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University of Ibadan, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Osayomi, T., Department of Geography, University of Ibadan, Nigeria; Areola, A.A., Department of Geography, University of Ibadan, Nigeria
Abstract: RTAs in Nigeria are very high and have become progressively important because of their heavy health and financial burden. The few geographic studies on RTAs in Nigeria are limited to their mere spatial distribution and associated risk factors, with very little attention given to their spatial clustering patterns and the detection of hotspots. With the aid of Global Moran's I and Local Getis, the study found some evidence of significant positive spatial autocorrelation, and consistent clustering of RTAs, RTIs and RTDs in the southwest from 2002 to 2007 which suggested the presence of an accident belt in the southwestern region, which has been accounted by poor road infrastructure, relatively high level of economic development and high vehicular movements. The study recommends the deployment of road safety officials to the accident belt, strict enforcement of safety belts and helmets, and periodic road maintenance. © 2015 Faculty of Geography UGM and The Indonesian Geographers Association.

Title: Natural resources investment of oil and gas and regional development impact on community empowerment
Affiliations: Program of Regional Planning, Sumatera Utara University, Medan, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Baik, R.N., Program of Regional Planning, Sumatera Utara University, Medan, Indonesia
Abstract: This study was done in Bekasi district, at West Java, Indonesia, with the aims to analyze the management of upstream activities (exploration and production) of oil and gas industry and its impact on improving the quality of infrastructure, the equal benefits proportion for the corporation, local government and society, and CSR programs that would affect the community empowerment. The analysis would be calculated based on the per capita income, the number of medical personals, and the number of teachers. Based on that calculation, this study analyzed the impact of oil and gas activities to the regional development of the area under this study. Analysis of regional development was calculated through number of industry in the area, the economic growth, and local government revenue that affects community empowerment in Bekasi. Analyzed by structural equation modeling (SEM), the results showed that: (1) management of upstream oil and gas activities in this area have a positive influence, but no significant effect on community empowerment; (2) management of upstream oil and gas activities have a significant positive impact on regional development; (3) regional development has a significant positive impact on community empowerment; (4) management of upstream oil and gas activities have a greater positive influence towards community empowerment through regional development, because of the multiplier effect of the development of the region. © 2015 Faculty of Geography UGM and The Indonesian Geographers Association.

Title: Relationships between Sea Surface Temperature (SST) and rainfall distribution pattern in South-Central Java, Indonesia
Affiliations: Department of Agricultural Engineering, Faculty of Agricultural Technology, Universitas Gadjah Mada, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Nugroho, B.D.A., Department of Agricultural Engineering, Faculty of Agricultural Technology, Universitas Gadjah Mada, Indonesia
Abstract: Although there has been a high relationship between global climate and rainfall in Indonesia, little evidence is available for relationship between Sea Surface Temperature (SST) and rainfall pattern in highland of country. This study evaluates the relationships between Sea Surface Temperature (SST) and rainfall distribution pattern in Gunungkidul district, highland of South-Central Java, Indonesia. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) approach was used to summarize the average of SSTs during rainy season (October to March) for the El Niño monitoring regions: IOBW (Indian Ocean Basin-Wide), Niño. West and Niño. 3. Monthly rainfall data was collected from Agricultural Government of Gunungkidul district. In this area, rainfall was highest in the southern and western mountainous areas, especially near the coast, and SSTs values were highly correlated with rainfall in those areas. Almost all sub districts in Gunungkidul district has significant correlations between PC1 SSTs and rainfall during October-November-December (OND). © 2015 Faculty of Geography UGM and The Indonesian Geographers Association.

Authors: Resosudarmo I.A.N.P., Resosudarmo B.P., Isham B.A.
Title: The Indonesian clean river program (Prokasih) as perceived by the people residing along the rivers in Jakarta
Authors with affiliations: Resosudarmo, I.A.N.P.; Resosudarmo, B.P.; Isham, B.A.
Abstract: Recognizing the importance of clean river water, the Indonesian government began to implement a national clean river program in 1989. The program was commonly known as the Prokasih and concentrated on segments of rivers throughout Indonesia. The Prokasih has been considered successful because the pollutant concentrations in these segments have decreased. This study examines the Prokasih from the perspective of ordinary people. The study evaluates their perception of the easily observable characteristics of specific segments of three rivers participating in the Prokasih. These rivers are located in Jakarta, and they are the Ciliwung, Cipinang, and Mookervart rivers. The target respondents were the people living in close proximity to these rivers. Two important findings emerge from this study. First, people residing close to Ciliwung, Cipinang, and Mookervart rivers believe that, with regard to physical characteristics such as odor, color, mud (sediments), turbidity, suds (foam), trash, and flow, the river's conditions have worsened, even after the implementation of the Prokasih. Second, the majority of the people who reside along the three rivers and who are familiar with the Prokasih believe that the Prokasih has not played any positive role in preserving the river quality. From the two findings just mentioned, it can be concluded that river communities might not feel the benefits of a clean river program that is successful in lowering the technical parameters of water pollution, such as coliform, BOD, and COD.
Index Keywords: developing country; pollution control; programme evaluation; residents' perception; river pollution; water quality; Indonesia, Java, Jakarta

Title: The contribution of aerial photographs in evaluation of Bribin catchment area, Gunung Kidul, Yogyakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gunawan, T.
Abstract: This article presents findings of the research carried out in Bribin catchment, Gunung Kidul Regency, Yogyakarta Special Province, Indonesia. The research aims at finding out how aerial photographs help in evaluating the characteristics of karst hydrology in the study area, and also to idenfity ways of preserving limestone karst topography within the study area. In this study, the researcher used remote sensing techniques with SPOT images, and panchromatic as well as infrared aerial photographs scaled at 1:50 000 and 1:30 000 respectively. Field work was also employed in primary data collection. To identify the hydroloigc potential phenomena that need to be preserved, spatial and qualitative analysis methods were used. Results indicate that hydrologic divide of the Bribin catchment area can easily be delinaeted on aerial photographs for Oya/Sambipitu formation but difficult for limestone karst formation. Landform units in karst topography were identified and delineated basing on the density of limestone hills and solution process using aerial photographs. On the other hand, hydrologic occurrences such as stream flow comes out and suddenly cuts into the cave, springs and sinkholes which appeared very clearly on the infrared aerial photographs, emerge in karst topography. Hydrologic phenomena were inferred by land slope and length of dry valley as uvalas lineament. Groundwater subsurface flow in karst topography could be traced from Tambakromo cave and its proceeds on to the Gilap cave in the southeast and finally to the Jomblang cave in the south. From this point, the flow follows three directions, that is, towards the east (Brokomo-Pricimantoro), to the south (Southern coast), and to the southwest (Bribin cave). Basing on the findings it was recommended that Oya/Sambipitu formation which is situated on the northern part of Bribin catchment be the first priority to preserve, and to be followed by spring belts and high density limestone karst hills that were found out to be recharge areas.
Index Keywords: aerial photograph; catchment; hydrological cycle; karst hydrology; limestone; remote sensing; Indonesia, Yogyakarta, Bribin

Title: Non farm employment in the context of growing rural-urban linkages. (The case of corridor villages in Yogyakarta Special Region - Indonesia)
Authors with affiliations: Rijanta, R.
Abstract: An intensive single visit survey and rapid rural appraisal are conducted, covering three villages (Maguwoharjo, Kembang, Putat) in Yogyakarta Special Region. To some extent a qualitative information is also available for two additional villages of Pendowoharjo and Murtigading. This enables to draw a more complete picture of rural-urban linkage from and to all directions between Yogyakarta Municipality and its vicinity. The study reveals that the surveyed villages have experienced a great spatial and socio-economic transformation. Continuous provision of infrastructural support from the government has led to a better integration of rural areas to the main regional center of Yogyakarta Municipality. The most evident spatial changes are found in terms of land use in the main corridors from Yogyakarta Municipality to various directions. Employment structure is characterized by the importance of non-farm activities related to the urban sector. Service and trading activities are the most important source of employment for those who conduct commuting, either as employees or independent workers in both urban formal and informal sectors. Another type of non-farm employment is food processing and services are to be found in situ in the growing rural urban zone. This type of employment is simply a form of adjustment to local circumstances in which higher population density provides more accessible threshold for various goods and services offered. Sectoral and spatial linkages of the existing non-farm employment is rather limited in terms of economic multiplier effects. Further employment and income generation linkages are almost negligible. Finally, two sets of policy options consisting of agricultural development and infrastructural provision are proposed in order to anticipate the growing importance of rural urban linkage in the future for the benefit of the rural areas.
Index Keywords: agricultural development; infrastructural provision; labour absorption; land use change; off-farm employment; rural-urban linkage; Indonesia, Java, Yogyakarta

Title: Urban growth, informal sector and poverty
Authors with affiliations: Effendi, T.N.
Abstract: This article is focused on the effect of economic development, especially urban development, upon informal activities and the urban poor in Indonesia. The gist of this article is that although an impressive record of economic growth had been achieved during PJP I (The First Long Term Development Strategy), the urban informal activities and urban poor still seemed to experience the same problems. Partly as a result of the development implemented these tend to be concentrated in urban areas of Java, especially around the primate city of Jakarta. This inequality of development not only affected the performance of development activities but has also hindered the spread of employment opportunities to other areas, both rural and urban. Consequently, most of the urban labour force has been obliged to remain involved in informal activities, and therefore to stay in poor conditions.
Index Keywords: employment; informal sector; poverty; urban development; Indonesia, Java

Title: Forest fire monitoring using subresolution dimension of NOAA/AVHRR images in Kalimantan - 1995
Authors with affiliations: Usman, A.B.; Hartono
Abstract: After 1995, forest fire monitoring using subresolution dimension has developed tremendously. This paper presents finding of the research on forest fire monitoring in Central Kalimantan. In this research, forest fire monitoring was done basing on high response against heat change in channel 3 of NOAA AVHRR satellite images. Inspection was carried out between 11 September and 7 December 1985 at a Small Satellite Ground Station in Palangkaraya, Centrasl Kalimantan. The threshold value that were used are the brightness temperature of channel 3 > 315 K, the difference of brightness temperature of channel 3 and 4 > 15K, and albedo of channel 12 < 17.5%. Results of image inspection and field verification show that the smallest forest fire dimension detected is 1500 m2. The inspection was based on the concept of Harris et al. 1995. It was possible to localize the fire position at one sector on the pixel and every fire point that was detected on image could be detected at more than one pixels.
Index Keywords: AVHRR; developing country; fire monitoring; forest fire; forest management; hazard monitoring; natural hazard; NOAA; remote sensing; wildlife; Indonesia, Kalimantan

Title: Natural disaster mitigation and management in Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sudibyakto; Haroonah, N.
Abstract: Geologically and geographically, Indonesia is located in an area which is volcanically and tectonically active, in the wet tropical region. Due to this location, Indonesia is very vulnerable to a number of natural disasters which among others include: volcanic eruptions, earthquakes, waves (tsunami), flooding, drought, and landsliding. The effects of natural disasters are usually punitive in densely populated areas. There is a tendency in the increase of the types of disasters, number of victims, loss of property, and materials from time to time in Indonesia. The efforts geared towards the reduction of the effects, consequences, and risks of natural disasters (mitigation) need to be improved through the application of science and technology.
Index Keywords: disaster mitigation; hazard management; Indonesia

Title: Popular perception and participation in land and water conservation: a case of Wonogiri District
Authors with affiliations: Sutanto, A.
Abstract: In comparison with lowland area, the upland area has been less prioritized in the development scheme and relatively left behind in the introduction of productive technology. Additionally, physical condition of the dry-upland becomes major problem for people to gain a better welfare. There is now steadily an increasing government concern and awareness of the importance of this area. Despite the development equity jargon, the recognition of the significance of upland lies to the face that upland position is not only substantial but also decisive within watershed system. Land and water conservation work on these spheres of upland attractiveness. The study is directed to the inventory of this land and water conservation activities as a mean of development interventions to upland. Furthermore, appraising popular perception and participation in the activities is also the main part of the objective of the study. To facilitate this objective achievement, the study is purposely conducted in one of upland regency in Central Java, namely Wonogir. Two villages within the regency have been selected on the basis of agro-ecological stratification and within each village an amount of 150 farmer respondents has been randomly selected and interviewed.
Index Keywords: developing country; development planning; land conservation; popular participation; popular perception; upland management; water conservation; Indonesia, Java, Wonogiri

Title: Development of the rural non-farm economy on Java: a search for roots and determinative factors
Authors with affiliations: Huisman, H.; Kragten, M.
Abstract: Ever since a number of centuries non-agricultural activities play an important role in the rural eocnomy of Java. The last decades, their significance has increased further. Presently, close to half of both primary employment and income in rural Java originate from outside the agricultural sector. In this contribution, the history of rural industry on Java is outlined and the recent developments in its rural economy are subsequently summarized. Ensuing this, result from both enterprise and household surveys as recently carried out in the Special Province of Yogyakarta are presented and analysed. This with a view to assess whether the behaviour of the various components of the rural non-farm economy in the area is in line with developments in South East Asia as a whole as sketched by Saith 1992 in his well-known publication on the rural non-farm economy in developing countries. A number of conclusions are arrived at pertaining to the relevance and applicability of his model to the Javanese context. Finally, an assessment of the prospects of rural industry in this part of Indonesia is presented and contrasted with his findings.
Index Keywords: developing country; economic development; non-agricultural activity; rural economy; rural industry; Indonesia, Java

Title: Geomorphology of Yogyakarta area and its surrounding proposed as a geomorphological field laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Sutikno
Abstract: Almost all of the genetic geomorphological units exist in this area, except glacial. The geomorphological land classification closely relate to the physical environment components such as topography, soil, hydrology and land use/land cover. The geomorphological land classifications also reflect natural hazards such as flood, drought, erosion, massmovement and volcanic (nue ardente and lahars flow). Based on the completeness of geomorphological phenomena, Yogyakarta area and its surroundings show promise as a training area (field laboratory) for students from geography, physical, geography, geomorphology and other earth sciences.

Title: Variation of nocturnal surface temperature within suburban residential land use: a case study on suburban Fairfield, western Sydney, Australia

Abstract: This article deals with nocturnal variation of surface temperature within suburban Fairfield, Western Sydney, based on field observations. The data was acquired by traversing a route consisted of 45 measurement points. The measurements were conducted at 6, 7, 8 and 9pm respectively. The results show that there were both spatial and temporal variations of surface temperature over the study area, particularly when the individual surface type was considered. It was observed that the variations are caused by some factors, i.e. anthropogenic heat, radiation trapping, wind shelter and katabatic flow. Title: The perceptions and aspirations of people residing in the dangerous zone of Merapi volcano on their settlement environment
Authors with affiliations: Yunus, H.S.
Abstract: This article attempts find out the behavioural characteristics of people residing in the dangerous zone of Merapi volcano relating to their aspirations and perceptions of their settlement environment. The research is based on in-depth interviews. The research has been realised through co-operation between the Faculty of Geography Gadjah Mada University and the Department of Transmigration, Yogyakarta Special Province. Three sample areas are located on the volcanic slopes of the volcano, classified as the most dangerous zone, whereas the other three are located along the banks of river flowing down from the Merapi volcano. The first group is dangerous because of nuee ardente whereas the second group is dangerous because of the so-called rain lahar flows. The result of the research shows that most respondents (65%) do not feel agraid of the danger of either the nuee ardente or the rain lahar, 18% feel afraid and the rest (17%) very afraid of the danger. 94% of people wish to remain living in the village and only 6% of them would like to move.

Title: Agricultural production and land-use pattern in Kgatleng District, Botswana
Authors with affiliations: Lado, C.
Abstract: Land-use is in a continuous process of change either planned or otherwise. An increase in population has resulted into additional need for more agricultural land. The cattle population has increased relatively in line with population growth. This paper examines the changes in land-use pattern related to crop production and cattle rearing. Traditionally, crop production and cattle raising were conducted as separate enterprises. However, cattle have been recently kept on agricultural land, thus leading to extensive crop damage. In Kgatleng district, this development occurred in the 1920s with the establishment of the borehole scheme. Grazing areas are considered to be overrulitized, hence necessitating land-use intensification, including the adoption of 'modern' agricultural techniques and practices so as to minimize land deterioration and achieve sustainable production.

Title: The eruption of Merapi volcano, November 22, 1994: a geographical review
Authors with affiliations: Sudibyakto; Abasi, S.H.
Abstract: This paper discusses the extent of the eruption of the Merapi volcano on 22 November 1994. It looks at the effects associated with the volcano as it erupted in 1994. The damages were inflicted on both the abiotic and biotic environments. The eruption occurred in the southern parts of the volcano and the nuee ardente was witnessed between Turgo and Kaliurang hills via the Boyong river. Various volcanic materials were emitted on to the surface, including lava flows, gases, volcanic ash, sand and big blocks. The heavy rainfall which accompanied the eruption led to the formation of rain lahars, which also posed a threat in the lower portions of the volcano. Hugh volumes of volcanic materials found their way into the Boyong river and neighbouring rivers in the west, resulting in lahar floods. Some prognoses have been put forward as predictions or the outcomes of Merapi eruption both in the short-term and the long-term. These are only estimations intended to judge the consequences which may be desirable or undesirable. This situation has called for government involvement in an attempt to mimize casualties. This has been enabled through intergovernmental co-operation through the establishment of disaster prevention projects like the Sabo Technical Centre, Merapi Volcano Project and the office concerned with the investigation of the activites of Merapi. These projects have been combined in an attempt to establish hazard maps of the area.

Abstract: The rapid development of applied geomorphology is rooted in the improved scientific concepts and research methodologies. Abstract: On a valleyside slope in the study area (Murcia Province, Spain), there is an almost continuous, extremely well-defined surface layer of colluvium, resting with marked unconformity on subjacent materials. The latter materials may be relatively fresh bedrock, weathered rock or cemented gravels (older colluvial deposits). The younger colluvial layer transgresses all of these with little apparent change in general appearance, extending into relatively thick, recent valley fills. The term "recent' is used here to refer to the surface layer of valley fill which is a predominantly fine grained, unconsolidated, essentially non-stratified deposit which is the stratigraphic contemporary of the colluvial layer. This recent "fill' rests with marked unconformity on either bedrock or older, well stratified "fill' characterised by cemented gravel beds. Title: Some aspects of food security and social stress in the African arid and semi-arid environments

Abstract: This paper discusses critically, the theoretical dimension of food security and social stress in the African arid and semi-arid environments. Abstract: The last decades, rural East and Southeast Asia have been experiencing remarkable economic transformations. Abstract: Water supply in Yogyakarta municipality is mainly originated from two main sources, the pipe water and groundwater. The pipe water which is operated by the local drinking water authority does not suffice for the water demand of the people in the city. Title: Spatial and social differentiation in the use of rural community services on Java: an example from Bantul District, Special Province of Yogyakarta

Abstract: Since the early 1970s, the Indonesian government has given key attention to the provision of basic social services to the rural population. Authors with affiliations: Bintarto, R., Dept Human Geog, Faculty of Geog, Gadjah Mada Univ, Indonesia.
Abstract: Developing countries are usually characterized by a low economic structure, widespread poverty and rapid population increase. The geographer, therefore, has an academic and moral obligation to be active in applying practical analyses to the development problems.
